Technical Assistance Report
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
Project Number: 37049  
Project Preparatory Technical Assistance (PPTA) 
September 2011 
 
 
 
Republic of Indonesia: Preparing the Integrated 
Citarum Water Resources Management Investment 
Program Periodic Financing Request 2 
(Financed by the Japan Fund for Poverty Reduction)

PROJECT PREPARATORY TECHNICAL ASSISTANCE. 
 
A.  Justification 
1.  The Government of Indonesia requested for ADB’s assistance to prepare the Periodic 
Financing  Request  2  (PFR  2)  of  the  Integrated  Citarum  Water  Resources  Management 
Investment  Program,  for  addressing  the  shortage  of  water  supply  in  Bandung  and  its 
surrounding areas and conserving the upper watershed.  
 
2.  The  Citarum  river  basin  located  in  the  province  of  West  Java  is  socially  and 
economically the most important river basin in Indonesia. The basin provides around 80% of the 
surface water supply to the capital city of Jakarta and surrounding areas supporting a population 
of about 30 million and contributing 20% of the country’s industrial outputs. In addition, the river 
fed irrigation schemes produce 5% of the country’s rice production. Sustainable management of 
the surface and ground water in the river basin is, therefore, critical to the country’s economic 
development and food security. Furthermore, water quality degradation is compromising public 
health and livelihoods, particularly of the rural and urban poor, and incurs additional economic 
and financial costs related to the delivery of clean and reliable water supplies. 
 
3.  Following  the  enactment  of  the  Water  Law  in  2004,  the  Government  adopted  an 
integrated approach to improving land and water management in the Citarum river basin, for 
which it requested ADB’s technical assistance (TA) in 2006. The TA helped develop a strategic 
integrated water resources management (IWRM) roadmap for the basin management with a 
shared vision, which is “the government and communities working together for clean, healthy 
and productive watersheds and rivers, bringing sustainable benefits to all people of the Citarum 
River Basin across Citarum basin stakeholders”.  
 
4.  In 2008, ADB approved a Multitranche Financing Facility (MFF) not exceeding $500 
million equivalent for the Integrated Citarum Water Resources Investment Program (Investment 
Program).1 The expected outcome of the Investment Program is improved and integrated water 
resources management in the Citarum river basin. The Investment Program comprises of the 
following interventions, namely: (i) establishing good IWRM institutions and effective planning 
with stakeholder participation; (ii) introducing effective planning, implementation and operation 
and maintenance of water resource infrastructure; (iii) establishing and protecting water rights 
and water allocation among competing uses and users; (iv) introducing environmental protection 
and  environmental  enhancement;  (v)  improving  disaster  management;  (vi)  empowering 
communities in water management; and (vii) enhancing data collection and decision support for 
water resources management. 
 
5.  ADB also approved in 2008 the PFR 1 under the MFF for (i) effective stakeholder 
coordination for IWRM roadmap management in the Citarum river basin; (ii) water resources 
development  and  management,  including  (a)  rehabilitation  of  the  West  Tarum  canal,  (b) 
improved land and water management, (c) support community driven initiatives for improved 
water supply and sanitation, and (d) detailed engineering design for upgrading Bandung water

sources;  and  (iii)  environment  protection.2 ADB  subsequently  approved  administration  of  a 
$3.75 million Global Environmental Facility (GEF) grant3 to support the PFR 1 activities.4  
 
6.  Although there were initial delays in PFR 1 implementation because of late mobilization 
of  the  consultants,  project  implementation  is currently  on  track  for most  components.  The 
progress has been satisfactory in the establishment of Project Implementation Units (PIUs) and 
the  fielding  of  TA  and  loan  consultants.  This  has  been  facilitated  by  strong  support  from 
Indonesia Resident Mission and ADB water sector team. The lessons learned include that the 
project administration in the country office could expedite project implementation and promptly 
address critical implementation issues including resettlement.     
 
7.  While PFR 1 implementation is progressing to strengthen basin wide water governance 
and management capacity, demand and competition for Citarum water resources has increased 
significantly  over  the  past  20  years.  Watershed  degradation,  rapid  urbanization  and 
industrialization in the area and slow development of surface water sources have created an 
overdependence on groundwater as a primary source of water. Consequently, the rate of water 
extraction from local aquifers significantly exceeds recharge rates, with water tables declining at 
more than 1 meter a year in some places. This has led to acute water stress and depletion of 
aquifers in major urban areas such as Bandung. Current water supply capacity in the Bandung 
and its surrounding area is only 3,800 liters per second (lps) compared to the requirements of 
5,100 lps in 2010.5 Due to rapid urbanization, its population is expected to increase from 8.0 
million in 2010 to 9.5 million and water supply demand to 9,200 lps by 2018. Therefore, the 
current  and  emerging  acute  water  supply  shortage  in  the  area  needs  to  be  addressed 
expeditiously.   
 
8.  Moreover, the hydrologic flow regime in the Citarum river basin on which Bandung water 
supply depends has been also adversely affected by land degradation, notably the loss of forest 
cover  and  unsustainable  farming  practices  on  steep  slopes  in  the  upper  catchments.  The 
degraded catchments have reduced capacity to capture rainwater, resulting in high peak flows 
during the rainy season causing downstream flooding and high soil erosion rates. It is estimated 
that 25% of the basin area has erosion rates in excess of 210 tons per ha per year.  
 
9.  To effectively address the problems of degrading watershed and acute water stress and 
depletion of aquifers in Bandung and its surrounding areas, the Government requested ADB in 
2010 to support the preparation of PFR 2 for financing under the Investment Program. PFR 2 
will  improve  Bandung  water  supply  by  developing  adequate  surface  water  resources  and 
providing raw water to the provincial water supply companies (PDAMs), thereby reducing the 
dependence and overexploitation of groundwater. It will also address the upper watershed 
degradation. The basic project information is presented in Appendix 1.  
 
10.  PFR 2 will complement, and coordinate with, the World Bank support to the Directorate 
General  of  Human  Settlement  (DGHS),  Ministry  of  Public  Works  and  related  government 
agencies. ADB and the World Bank have agreed on collaboration mechanisms for (i) solid

11.  PFR 2 supports the national economic and water resource sector development priorities 
and investment plans, particularly the Economic Development Masterplan for 2011-2025.6 PFR2 
is included in the ADB’s Indonesia Operations Business Plan for 2010-2013 and is consistent 
with development priorities of other development partners involved in the water resources sector. 
 
B.  Major Outputs and Activities 
12.  The TA will (i) prepare a bulk water supply master plan; (ii) prepare an option study for 
the  bulk  water  supply;  (iii)  feasibility  study  (FS),  which  includes  investigative  surveys, 
preliminary designs,  cost estimates, technical, financial, and economic analysis, environment 
analysis, social impact assessment, a baseline survey for project indicators, and a project 
administration manual; (iv) preparation of TOR and tender documents for detailed design of the 
selected options and initiate the tender process with consultants; (v) groundwater management 
plan for Bandung Basin, (vi) upper catch management and development program, and (vii) 
scope for PFR 3 as well as a preparation facility for PFR 3.

D.  Consulting Services 
 
15.  Consultants will be engaged through a firm, indicatively for 29 person-months (PM) of 
international consultant inputs, and 65 PM of national consultant inputs. ADB will select and 
engage consultants in accordance with ADB’s Guidelines on the Use of Consultants (2010, as 
amended from time to time). The quality- and cost-based selection (QCBS), using full technical 
proposal procedure and 80:20 ratio, will be followed. The consultants may procure equipment 
through shopping in accordance with ADB’s Procurement Guidelines (2010, as amended from 
time to time). Upon completion of the TA, equipment procured under the TA will be transferred 
to the EA. All the consultants need to have university degree in the related field and at least five 
years experience in water supply or related projects in Indonesia.

16.  Water Resources Planner/Team Leader (international, 8 PM). The responsibility is to 
act as a team leader of the consultant team and manage the consulting services, providing work 
programs and updated staff schedules when required, and submit progress reports to the 
executing agency, implementing agencies and ADB. The consultant should be responsible for 
the preparation of the draft bulk water supply master plan, options study, and feasibility study, 
and groundwater management plan. The consultant needs to assist Balai Besar Wilayah Sungai 
Citarum (BBWSC) in recruiting the detailed design consultants, and assist the Directorate of 
Water Resources and Irrigation, State Ministry of National Development Planning (BAPPENAS), 
the executing agency of the TA in preparing the PFR 2 document.   
 
17.  Groundwater  Specialist  (international,  3  PM).    The  consultant  is  responsible  for 
preparing a ground water management study and an assessment of hydrogeological conditions 
in  the  project  area,  including  assessments  on  use  of  shallow  groundwater  for  domestic 
consumption and deep groundwater used by industry, the volumes of water abstracted legally, 
and an estimate of illegal abstractions. 
 
18.  Senior Water Resources Engineer (international, 4 PM). The consultant should have 5 
years experience in water sector projects as well as have designed dams, spillways, weirs, 
intakes and pipelines in Indonesia. The consultant should evaluate the technical aspects of 
proposed options. 
 
19.  Senior Water Supply Engineer (international, 2 PM). The responsibility is to assess the 
previous water supply planning documents and the DGHS master plan for water supply in order 
to assess existing and future demands, demand centers and locations of proposed treatment 
plants,  evaluate  water  savings  that  could  be  made  through  leak  detection  and  other 
improvements in O&M, confirm proposed plans for system expansion and hence the need and 
demands for new bulk water sources over a 25 year horizon. 
 
20.  Geotechnical Engineer (international, 2 PM). The consultant is responsible for carrying 
out a desk study to review the locations of structures proposed as bulk water sources using

geological maps, references and satellite imagery and identify those with concerns about their 
geology or with serious seismic risk. 
 
21.  Project  Economist/Financial  Management  Specialist  (international,  3  PM).  The 
consultant is responsible for economic and financial analysis of proposed subprojects, feasibility 
studies and financial planning. 
 
22.  Social Development/Resettlement Specialist (international, 3 PM). The consultant is 
responsible for preparing safeguard reports and poverty, social and gender analysis, including 
social  impact  assessment,  resettlement  framework,  resettlement  plans,  summary  poverty 
reduction and social strategy, summary social and poverty assessment.

responsibility is to prepare the watershed protection components of the feasibility studies and 
master  plan,  a  water  quality  report  of  the  proposed  bulk  water  supply  scheme,  and  the 
environment impact assessment for meeting environment safeguards requirements.

to assess the surface and ground water potential as well as domestic, municipal, industrial, 
irrigation and aquaculture demands and assess needs of other water uses such as hydropower 
and flood management.  
 
25.  Hydrologist (national, 4 PM). The consultant is responsible for collecting hydrological 
and climate data and reports on all long listed options and analyzing the hydrological data for 
the bulk water supply master plan and proposed water supply schemes.  
 
26.  Groundwater Specialist (national, 3 PM). The consultant is responsible for collecting 
data, reports and mapping of ground water sources in the upper Citarum river basin, including 
reports on groundwater abstraction by industry, surveys on land settlement, extraction from 
wells, tubewells and deep aquifer pumping and potential spring sources. 
 
27.  Water Supply Engineer (national, 5 PM). The responsibility is to collect planning data 
on water supply in Bandung and its surrounding areas, including information gathered and 
produced by DGHS as part of their water supply master plan. 
 
28.  Water  Resources  Engineer  (national,  5  PM).  The  consultant  is  responsible  for 
collecting reports and design material on the various options proposed for bulk water supply as

29.  Hydraulic Structure Engineer (national, 3 PM). The consultant’s responsibility is to

E.  Implementation Arrangements 
 
39.  The Directorate of Water Resources and Irrigation, Ministry of National Development 
Planning (BAPPENAS) will be the executing agency of the TA. Implementing agencies will be 
BBWSC and West Java Agency of Development Planning (BAPPEDA). BBWSC will prepare a 
bulk water supply master plan and action plans, feasibility study in consultation with Directorate 
General  of  Human  Settlement,  West  Java  Provincial  Human  Settlement  Department,  and 
provincial  water  supply  companies.  BAPPEDA  will  be  another  implementing  agency  for 
watershed  management  activities,  including  sustainable  agriculture  practices  and  forestry 
activities. The executing agency and implementing agencies will provide in-kind contributions of 
office accommodation, transport, counterpart staff, and report, data, and preliminary design of 
the bulk water supply system.  
 
40.  The TA will be implemented for 18 months from 1 January 2012 to 28 June 2013. All 
procurement shall be in accordance with the Procurement Guidelines, (2010, as amended from 
time to time). The Guidelines on the Use of Consultants (2010, as amended from time to time) 
will be applied in the recruitment of consultants. Disbursements under the TA will be done in

I. POVERTY ISSUES
A.  Links to the National Poverty Reduction Strategy and Country Partnership Strategy 
The Government of Indonesia supports the water resources sector as a priority in the Medium-term Development Plan 
(RPJMN) for 2010-2014 and the project as a priority in the Country Partnership Strategy and Indonesia Country 
Operations Business Plan for 2011-2013. The sector analysis in the RPJMN indicates that the water resources are 
under serious threat because of declining availability of water resources due to high land conversion, water pollution, 
excessive exploitation of ground water, and climate change impact. Raw water supply service is neither optimal nor 
equitable due to the declining flow of water sources and high rate of sedimentation in the river basin. On the other 
hand, the demand of raw water supply is higher due to rapid population growth, and inefficient pattern of water 
utilization. The development of irrigation management has not yet been optimized. So far only 11% of irrigated area 
relies on the availability of water from reservoir, the rest relies on river.  
 
The country’s water resources development strategy aims to improving the welfare of society and contributes to 
poverty reduction efforts. The number of poor people in Indonesia is 31 million (13%) and most of them (20 million, 
64%) live in rural area. The target of poverty reduction in the RPJMN is to reduce the poverty to 10% by 2014. The 
Government’s strategy of the poverty reduction is to improve the economic growth in the sectors that have significant 
impact in achieving MDGs. These include improvement of agricultural productivity and increased access of poor 
people to water supply for domestic and agriculture needs, which can be possible in the Citarum river basin. 
   
The project focusing on Bandung and its surrounding area is in line with the Government of Indonesia’s strategies for 
water resources development and poverty reduction.  It is also in line with ADB Country Partnership Strategy (2011-
2013 scheduled for approval in 2011) which focuses on ADB’s role in advancing the social development agenda to 
empower the poor in order to benefit from growth. The Project is also supporting ADB Water for All policy. The project 
will benefit general population in the project area including many of those who are under the poverty line.

2.   Explain the basis for the targeting classification:  
The project will contribute to the MDG Goal 7, Target 3, reduction by half of the proportion of the population without 
sustainable access to safe drinking water through expansion of water supply and improvement water service. The 
government’s MDG target for drinking water service in the big cities including Bandung City is 80%.

II.  SOCIAL DEVELOPMENT ISSUES
A.  Initial Social Analysis 
Based on existing information: 
 
1.  Who are the potential primary beneficiaries of the project? How do the poor and the socially excluded benefit 
from the project? 
PFR 2 will focus on Bandung and its surrounding areas. Total current population is 8.0 million, and it is projected as 
9.5 million in 2018, and 11.8 million in 2030. In parallel with the population increase, the needs for raw water are 
expected to increase significantly up to 9,200 liters/second by 2018. The project will improve health and livelihoods of 
8 million people in Bandung and its surrounding area, including the poor and the socially excluded due to better water 
supply for domestic need. The number of poor West Java population in 2007 was 5.5 million or 14%. The poor are 
concentrated in surrounding area of plantations, state forest, farms, and industrial area. In rural area, the poor are 
largely engaged in agriculture.  
  
2.  What are the potential needs of beneficiaries in relation to the proposed project? 
Poverty is most severe for those without secure access to water supply services. The potential needs of beneficiaries 
are mostly access to affordable clean drinking water and water for sanitation. Other need is for industries. Improved 
water resource management, increase knowledge and awareness of sanitation and water conservation are important 
for all stakeholders. To fulfill the needs of beneficiaries it is important for all stakeholders, including government, 
communities, private sector and nongovernment organizations (NGOs) to work in partnership and complimenting each 
other. 
  
3.  What are the potential constraints in accessing the proposed benefits and services, and how will the project 
address them? 
The project areas are Bandung and its surrounding area with limited water supply services because of the poor 
management of the provincial water supply companies. The implementation of water resources management suffers 
from weak coordination among the concerned parties, weak awareness and community participation in the water 
resources management. The legal aspect of water supply needs to be further reviewed by the project in connection 
with institutional, financial, and administrative aspects so that the project could recommend better options to improve 
water supply mechanism and the provincial water supply companies. Information about the project and awareness 
about the potential benefit of the project should be disseminated to all stakeholders in order to get their cooperation 
and supports.  
B.  Consultation and Participation 
1. Indicate the potential initial stakeholders.  
Stakeholders to be involved in the proposed project are (i) sectoral ministries and institutions including Ministry of 
Public Works, Ministry of Forestry, Ministry of Agriculture; (ii) provincial government and institutions, including West 
Java Department of Development Planning (Bappeda); (iii) district government; (iv) direct beneficiaries including poor 
people and women in Bandung and its surrounding area; (v) interest group including NGOs concerned on water 
resource working in the project area. The stakeholders and their capacity would be further identified and assessed 
during the PPTA.  
 
2. What type of consultation and participation is required during the PPTA or project processing (e.g., workshops, 
community mobilization, involvement of NGOs and community-based organizations (CBOs), etc.)? 
The project beneficiaries will be consulted during the TA implementation though stakeholder mapping and analysis 
inception workshop, midterm workshop and final workshop, which will involve all stakeholders, in particular NGOs and 
community  based  organizations.  Communication  plan  and  consultation  schedule  will  be  prepared  accordingly.

safe drinking water and it affects their health and productivity. Awareness raising and skill improvement related to 
water conservation, sanitation and clean water technology should be prioritized for women and their access to 
community management of water resources should be improved. Women should be consulted on the affordability of
